Thursday, May 3, 2007























FDA expands antidepressant warning to young adults 
Young adults beginning treatment with antidepressants should be warned about an increased risk of suicidal thoughts and behavior, federal health officials said Wednesday. The Food and Drug Administration proposed labeling changes that would broaden the "black box" warning that currently appears on all antidepressants, which applies only to children and adolescents, to include adults 18-24 during the first month or two of treatment with the drugs, the agency said.

Guide promotes Latin American Diet Pyramid 
A new food pyramid, designed to encourage Latinos to eat healthier, emphasizes the benefits of grains and tubers such as maize, quinoa and plantains, and tropical fruits such as mangos and papayas.

Experts skeptical of 'Master Cleanse' detox diet 
Mix lemon juice, maple syrup, bottled water and cayenne pepper and you've got a key element of the detoxifying diet known as the "Master Cleanse," touted by celebrities including Beyonce Knowles.

Unexpected heart problems seen in bone drugs 
Two research reports suggest a possible link between the bone-building drugs Fosamax and Reclast and irregular heart rhythms in a small number of women who take the medicine for osteoporosis.
FULL STORY






Hormone therapy may ward off dementia
New research suggests that hormone therapy taken soon after menopause may help protect against dementia, but it raises the risk of mental decline in those who do not take it until they are older.
